results.title: Living stone
results.creator_credit: John Feeney, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film shows the inspiration, often related to belief in the supernatural, behind Inuit sculpture. The Inuit’s approach to the work is to release the image he sees imprisoned in the rough stone. The film centres on an old legend about the carving of the image of a sea spirit to bring food to a hungry camp. Photographed at Cape Dorset, Boffin Island with Inuit stone carvers of Kingait and Kangiyak. Award winning documentary.

results.title: Living science: how materials are changed
results.creator_credit: United World Films and ACI Films
results.brief_description: Discusses characteristics and properties of chemical substances, concepts relating to the structure of matter, elements and compounds, how chemical changes occur and the importance of these changes in daily life. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Living Room
results.brief_description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. “Home is where to sleep” - Why do people live where they do? “Home is an extension of your personality” - Do people have a choice in the way they live? What does “home” mean? A photographic mosaic of faces and places, “Living Room” reveals surprising values and attitudes.

results.title: Living room
results.brief_description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. A photographic mosaic of faces and places, Living Room exposes the myths surrounding home ownership and the shrinking potential of home ownership and reveals surprising values and attitudes. The program raises questions about the lack of services and isolation associated with outer suburban life. It looks at our treatment of the elderly and the way the nuclear family and the dream of “owning your own home” have shaped our living environment.

results.title: Living reptile: the locomotion of snakes
results.creator_credit: James A. Oliver and New York Zoological Society
results.brief_description: This study of snake locomotion opens by showing the typical four-legged method of locomotion of animals and how it is related to the serpentine motion of the snake. Described in detail are the serpentine motion, employed by all snakes; the caterpillar motion used by some such as the Reticulated Python and the Puff Adder; the side-winding motion used chiefly by heaby-bodied desert snakes, and the hitch-and-hike or concertina method used by some snakes in climbing trees.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James A. Oliver and New York Zoological Society

results.title: Living outback on a farm
results.creator_credit: Nandor Jenes, Donald Batchelor and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Presents a view of life on a wheat farm in the Australian outback. Shows farming activities and indicates the necessity of a good water supply. Also shows the nearby town, local school and a picnic.

results.title: Living out loud [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Richard LaGravenese, Stacey Sher, Michael Shamberg, Danny DeVito, Jersey Films and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Living out loud was the directorial debut for screenwriter, Richard LaGravenese, who based this script on two stories by Anton Chekhov. Judith Nelson is a genteel uptown New Yorker, devastated by the news that her husband is leaving her for another woman. The aftershocks of this event forces Judith to question her personal presumptions and life choices that lead her to this juncture. We witness Judith’s inner turmoil, coming to terms with the lie of her marriage and the challenge to find an identity, other than wife, which will enable her to relate to others. A part of Judith’s journey is the blossoming of her friendship with Pat, the elevator operator in her building who is deeply indebted to shady gamblers, estranged from his wife and facing the death of his young daughter. Judith’s financial assistance of Pat and potential romance, as well as her friendship with a sultry nightclub singer, directs her on a path that crystallises her ambitions. This is a sensitively written film, impressive in its observations of the emotional lives of the protagonists and the struggles that ensue.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard LaGravenese, Stacey Sher, Michael Shamberg, Danny DeVito, Jersey Films and New Line Cinema

results.title: Living not dying
results.brief_description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia. “For the past six years, I have been living with, not dying from, advanced breast cancer. My original diagnosis was in 1996, when I was 40 years old.”

results.title: Living jazz
results.creator_credit: Jack Gold, John Hall, Paddy Whannel and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: A candid study of the Bruce Turner Jump Band at work, at individual and group practice rehearsal, on tour and as they discuss and arrange their music. Music written and arranged by Bruce Turner. Instruments: Bruce Turner (Alto Sax), John Mumford (Trombone), Johnny Chilton (Trumpet), Colin Bates (Piano), Jim Bray (Bass), Johnny Armitage (Drums). Presented by Doug Dobell and Ken Lindsay.
